nomenclature.name: Calamus gracilis
nomenclature.author: Roxb.
nomenclature.bibref: Beccari in Hook. f. Fl. Brit. Ind. 6:453. 1893
Beccari, Ann. Roy. Bot. Gard. Calcutta 11: 318. 1908 and Appendix Pl. 124. 1913.

treatment.div: A slender climber; stem cluster-forming, with leaf sheath 15-20 mm in diameter. Leaves ecirrate to 70 cm long; leafsheath with flagellum, armed with long and short needle-like spines; longest spines about 3 cm long; ocrea with distinct hairy projection; petiole to 3 cm long, concave-convex, armed with straight spines along the margins; rachis armed below with bulbous-based straight spines; leaflets in groups with 2-4 leaflets in each opposite groups, deflected in one plane, narrowly oblanceolatc, longer leaflets to 50 cm long, 1 cm wide at broadest part; lowermost leaflets to 25 cm long, 3-5 nerved on upper side; nerves more or less smooth on upper side, bristly on lower side; terminal leaflets two-third connate from base. Male and female inflorescences flagclli-form, delicately branched, axial part aculeate; male rachillac 3 - 5 cm long; male flowers distichous, 5 mm x 2 mm; female flowers horizontally projected from the rachilla. Fruits broadly ovoid, elliptic, 2.6-3 cm long, 1.4-1.7 cm broad, equally rounded on both sides; fruit scales straw-yellow in colour, deeply channelled at middle, arranged in 21 longitudinal series; seed ovoid; endosperm ruminate; embryo lateral in the middle of the outer face.
In evergreen forests, mostly at 1000-1500 m, in lower to middle hill forests of the Eastern Himalaya.
Cultivated in the Indian Botanic Garden, Howrah.
Its present availability in Bangladesh could not be confirmed due to non-availability of recent collections in any of the Bangladesh herbaria.
